oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Antibiotics are used for both group B streptococcal (GBS) prevention and treatment. Active population-based surveillance for invasive GBS disease was conducted in four states during 1996â€”2003. Of 3813 case-isolates, 91.0% (3471) were serotyped, 77.1% (2937) had susceptibility testing, and 46.6% (3471) had both. All were sensitive to penicillin, ampicillin, cefazolin, cefotaxime, and vancomycin. Clindamycin and erythromycin resistance was 12.7% and 25.6%, respectively, and associated with serotype V (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>P</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mn>.001</mml:mn></mml:math>). Clindamycin resistance increased from 10.5% to 15.0% (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msup><mml:mi>X</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msup></mml:math>for trend 12.70;<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>P</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mn>.001</mml:mn></mml:math>); inducible clindamycin resistance was associated with the<jats:italic>erm</jats:italic>genotype. Erythromycin resistance increased from 15.8% to 32.8% (<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:msup><mml:mi>X</mml:mi><mml:mn>2</mml:mn></mml:msup></mml:math>for trend 55.46;<mml:math xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mml:mi>P</mml:mi><mml:mo><</mml:mo><mml:mn>.001</mml:mn></mml:math>). While GBS remains susceptible to beta-lactams, resistance to alternative agents such as erythromycin and clindamycin is an increasing concern.</jats:p>
